content.description:
One of the more impressive routes on the Parkway, steep and sustained! In addition to the fact that you're climbing vertical ice most of the way, you have to deal with the overhanging mushrooms that form in the middle of the route. While not real difficult to climb, these mushrooms can make protection challenging. Climb up a short apron of ice to the base and then run the rope out to the middle of the route, encountering the mushrooms near the end of the pitch. Belay off screws and/or cord, usually on the right side of the route, but sometimes on the left. The second pitch starts out climbing mushrooms again, leading to better ice which is followed to the top of the route. Another very long pitch. Belay off screws and v-threads. Curtain Call is on the east side of the Parkway, about 14k north of the Icefields Visitor Center. You can't miss seeing it from the road.

Park off the road directly below the route. Approach through trees to the left of the route then back right up a steep and somewhat slippery slope below the route.

Rappel from v-threads or descend an avalanche prone slope to the right. A good selection of screws and cord for v-threads.

This route varies greatly from year to year, and the more ice there is the easier it will be.  It was a really cool line at the time of it's submission to MP, and is described as such.   
  
 P1, 65m, WI4+:  climb to the big ledge and a bolted belay rappel station. 
 P2, 60m, M7+, WI5+:  Hard drytooling mostly on small edges right off the deck, leads to the first ice blob.  Be wary of a loose flake to the right of the first blob, and position the belayer accordingly.  Then link more blobs to the big roof.  Clip a bolt under the roof and step across to the hanging ice curtain.  Commit to the ice curtain and climb excellent ice to a bolted station at the top.

This route is on the left margin of Curtain Call, about 10m to the left.
Draws for 10 bolts and 6 - 8 screws.  Bolted belay/rappel stations at the top of both pitches.

climbs.fa: Marc Moquin, Tom Saunders, Cyril and Sandra Shokoples, 1980

content.description:
There are three pitches, all ending at bolt anchors on the right side. Third pitch (40m) is the crux. Pitch 1 and 2 can be linked with a 70m rope. 
  
 After pitch 3 there are 3 additional pitches, particularly in the spring, which form higher up the gully and can make for a longer outing.

About half an hour south of Jasper on 93, near the Goat lookout. There's a pullout with an outhouse at the top of a hill.
Screws

A great moderate climb, usually done in three pitches. Park 4.5km North of the Beauty Creek Hostel. The climb is visible from the road, barely. Walk up a slightly graded (old road?) slope and gain the drainage. Descend climbers left. screws.

Descent: Rappel from trees on top and bolt anchors on the left side. Two 60m ropes are required to rappel.

climbs.name: Rick Blak Memorial Route
climbs.fa: Donna Nicholson, Ken Wallator, Brian Webster.  11/91

content.description:
Get this one when you can!  When it comes in, this rarely formed route is a narrow ribbon of ice in a shallow cleft.  It gets steep quickly, with the crux coming in the middle.  Climb to a belay/rappel anchor on the right.  There is an intermediate anchor on the right half way up.

This route is in the Beauty Creek area, which is just north of Curtain Call.  Park at a pullout a couple km north of the Curtain Call pullout.  If it's in, the route will be easily visible 100 m right of the wide flow, Shades of Beauty on the cliff to the south east.  Take the signed hiking trail to Beauty Creek, and hike up the left side of the drainage, until below the route.
Screws for pro, rappel from a chock stone anchor.

climbs.name: Shades of Beauty
climbs.fa: Mike Blenkarn, Iain Stewart-Patterson, Colin Zacharias, 1981

content.description:
P1 WI2-3 Two fun and easy steps lead to a ledge 
 P2 WI4 15m curtain to a bolt anchor at the back of the ledge on the left 
 P3 WI4 The money. Longer pitch to a bolt anchor under the overhang at the back of the ledge

52.9m north of Rampart Creek Hostel. Park at a pullout on the right and follow the old road. Take a trail left just on the left side of a drainage. After about 1.5km, you'll see the route up on your right. The trail will cross the stream below the route and was marked with a light-colored single-rock cairn on a large boulder in the middle of the stream.
Screws

The Stage is the left hand smear in the broad face of Tangle Ridge.  The route is clearly visible from the road.  There is significant avalanche hazard associated with the overhead gully that funnels debris right on to the climb.

Ice screws.  Double 60m ropes recommended to get down.

A nice easy climb.  Super easy approach:  park right at the Tangle Falls lookout and climb the obvious waterfall.  You can rap with a single 60m rope off the tree at the top left.  Good first lead.


Screws. There are a few sets of bolts/rings up top for LO.Â

The Wings is the right of two falls that form on this broad face.  It is between The Stage (left) and Curtain Call (right).

Ice screws and two 60's to get down.

This area encompasses mountains and routes on the Parkway that lie between Sunwapta Pass and Jasper.  Many popular and well-known routes are included in this area including the impressive ice route, Curtain Call, and the infamous alpine route, Slipstream.
